]] In mechanics, 'compression' is the application of opposite "pushing" forces
to a material or structure, that is, balanced forces directed so as to reduce
its size in one or more directions. It is contrasted with tension or traction,
the application of balanced "pulling" forces.

In 'uniaxial compression' the forces are directed along one direction only, so
that they act towards decreasing the object's length along that direction. The
compressive forces may also be applied in multiple directions; for example
inwards along the edges of a plate, acting to reduce its area, or inwards over
the entire surface of a body, acting to reduce its volume.

Technically, a material is under a state of compression, at some specific point
and along a specific direction u , if the normal component of the
stress vector across a surface with normal u is directed opposite
to u . If the stress vector itself is opposite to u ,
the material is said to be under 'normal compression' or 'pure compressive
stress' along u . In a solid, the amount of compression generally
depends on the direction u , and the material may be under
compression along some directions but under traction along others. If the
stress vector is purely compressive and has the same magnitude for all
directions, the material is said to be under 'isotropic' or 'hydrostatic
compression' at that point.
